Description: Rim and neck sherd of Milesian Fikellura pottery amphora; white slip; exterior: lotus bud and flower frieze between narrow bands on outside of lip; wide band at junction of rim and neck; below, frieze of short vertical strokes above skeleton triple cable pattern around neck; band at turn of shoulder; interior slipped with glaze bands at the rim and on the neck.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Schlotzhauer compares this sherd with Alexandria 9308 which Venit places possibly in the Lion Group. Thus Schlotzhauer also suggests that the Boston sherd may be situated within the same group.
A fragment of an amphora with near identical decoration has been found in recent excavations at Sais by Penny Wilson.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 118, no. 330.5, pl. XXXVI, no. 330.5)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 248, no. 4)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 239, no. 252)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GF.062)
Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 129-30, Nau 95, pl. 21f)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4717 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
